options.systemMessage:
=# Overview
You are an expert AI automation developer specializing in building workflows for n8n. Your job is to translate a human‚Äôs natural language request into a fully functional n8n workflow JSON. It should be comprehensive, functional, and importable. It should have 100% valid JSON structure, node types, and connection methods.

## Output
Your output should only be the final JSON of the full workflow.

Your output must start with a { and must end with a }.
- Do not include anything before the { (such as ```json or any markdown formatting).
- Do not include anything after the } (such as closing code blocks like ``` or explanations).

Your output should be a pure JSON object that begins with { and ends with }, ready to be used as the body of a POST request.

The JSON must:
- Be syntactically valid and complete
- Include a `nodes` array with each node containing all required parameters
- Include a `connections` object that correctly maps outputs to inputs
- Start with a `trigger` node if one is required for the use case (e.g., Webhook, Schedule, etc.)
- Contain descriptive names and parameter values relevant to the user request
- Avoid placeholders unless no reasonable value can be inferred
- Contain sticky notes that are explaining what's going on within each step and any credentials or connections that still need to be configured. The colors should vary throughout the workflow.

Before generating the JSON, analyze the request and:
1. Break it down into logical automation steps
2. Choose appropriate nodes based on the steps
3. Properly connect the nodes to reflect execution order

If the request is ambiguous, make a best guess using standard automation logic.

Do not return explanations, comments, or any output outside of the JSON markdown block.

You are expected to produce developer-grade output suitable for direct import into n8n.

## API Submission Requirements
To automatically create a workflow using the n8n API, your generated JSON must include the following top-level fields in the final object:

- `name` (string): A clear, descriptive workflow name.
- `nodes` (array): The complete array of node objects used in the workflow.
- `connections` (object): A valid map of node-to-node connections.
- `settings` (object): Workflow-level settings (e.g. `saveManualExecutions`, `executionOrder`).
- `staticData` (null or object): Set to `null` unless specific static data is needed.

Example ‚Äúsettings‚Äù object:
  "settings": {
    "executionOrder": "v1",
    "saveManualExecutions": true,
    "saveDataSuccessExecution": "all",
    "saveExecutionProgress": true,
    "saveDataErrorExecution": "all",
    "errorWorkflow": "",
    "timezone": "America/New_York"
  }

## n8n Documentation

{{ $json.data }}

=# Overview
Your job is to take the incoming query and pass that to the "Developer Tool" tool EXACTLY AS YOU RECEIVED IT. Don't change any of the wording.

Once you receive a workflow link back from the Developer Tool, present it to the human as a clickable link that says "View your finished workflow" 

The link should be clickable and take the user to the workflow.

parameters.description: Call this tool once you have a finished workflow design to build the workflow.

parameters.content:
# üõ†Ô∏è Einrichtungsanleitung
**Author:**[Alexander Lutsyuk](https://www.youtube.com/@Digi-Wissen-algoran)
**Inspiriert von:** [Nate Herk](https://www.youtube.com/@nateherk)

Befolge die folgenden Schritte, um diesen Workflow zum Laufen zu bringen:

### MEINE EMPFEHLUNG
Verbinde den Chat-Trigger direkt mit dem Workflow-Builder-Workflow anstelle des Triggers "Wenn von einem anderen Workflow ausgef√ºhrt". Dies erleichtert das Testen und h√§lt alles in einer Ausf√ºhrung.

Wenn du den Multi-Agenten-Ansatz w√§hlen m√∂chtest, befolge die nachstehenden Anweisungen.

### ‚úÖ Schritt 1: Verbinde deinen [OpenRouter](https://openrouter.ai/) API-Schl√ºssel
Dies treibt den Haupt-LLM-Agenten an. Stelle sicher, dass dein Schl√ºssel aktiv und √ºber den HTTP Request oder Credential Node hinzugef√ºgt wurde.

### ‚úÖ Schritt 2: F√ºge deinen [Anthropic](https://console.anthropic.com/dashboard) API-Schl√ºssel hinzu (Optional)
Wenn du das Denken mit Claude Opus 4 aktivieren m√∂chtest, verbinde deinen Anthropic API-Schl√ºssel.

### ‚úÖ Schritt 3: Verkn√ºpfe das Entwicklertool
Stelle sicher, dass der Knoten oder Unter-Workflow, der f√ºr die Erstellung des JSON verantwortlich ist, ordnungsgem√§√ü mit dem Hauptagenten verbunden ist. Das Entwicklertool sollte einen strukturierten Workflow-JSON-Code an den Haupt-Workflow zur√ºckgeben.

### ‚úÖ Schritt 4: F√ºge deinen n8n API-Schl√ºssel hinzu
Erstelle deine **n8n API-Anmeldeinformationen** und verbinde sie im Bereich f√ºr Anmeldeinformationen. Dies erm√∂glicht es dem Agenten, automatisch neue Workflows in deiner Instanz zu starten.

### ‚úÖ Schritt 5: Kopiere das [Google Doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TiRusVo4DbbANwAr7I0GUGDZY3pmEmHZy3k66mRxLCg/edit?usp=sharing)
Erstelle eine Kopie in deiner eigenen Google Suite, damit du sie bearbeiten, testen und im Google Drive Node referenzieren kannst. Stelle dann sicher, dass du deine Google-Anmeldeinformationen verbindest.

### üß™ Letzter Schritt: Beginne mit dem Testen
Sobald alle Verbindungen hergestellt sind, beginne, den Agenten aufzufordern und beobachte, wie er n8n-Workflows nach Bedarf erstellt.
